Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. First, I need to figure out which cases are taking significantly longer. To do that, I should calculate the duration for each case from Submit Claim to Close Claim. Looking at the table, each case has multiple entries. Let me list out each case's start and end times to compute their durations.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Starting with Case 2001: - Submit: 2024-04-01 09:00 - Close: 2024-04-01 10:30 Duration is 1 hour 30 minutes. That's pretty quick. Case 2002: - Submit: 2024-04-01 09:05 - Close: 2024-04-02 11:00 Hmm, that's from April 1st to April 2nd. Let's compute the days and hours. From 9:05 to 23:59 on the first day is about 14 hours 54 minutes, plus 11 hours on the second day. Total is around 25.9 hours, so roughly a day and a half? Wait, actually, subtract start time from end time. Let me do it properly: April 1st 09:05 to April 2nd 11:00 is 26 hours and 55 minutes. So about 26.9 hours. Case 2003: Submit: 2024-04-01 09:10 Close: 2024-04-03 09:30 So from April 1 to April 3. Let's compute that: April 1 start at 9:10, end on April 3rd at 9:30. That's two days and two hours 20 minutes. Total hours: 2*24 + 2.33 = 50.33 hours. Case 2004: Submit: 2024-04-01 09:20 Close: 2024-04-01 10:45. That's just 1 hour 25 minutes. Very quick. Case 2005: Submit: 2024-04-01 09:25 Close: 2024-04-04 14:30 So starting April 1st and ending April 4th. Let's compute: From April 1 09:25 to April 4 14:30 is 3 days and 5 hours 5 minutes. Total hours: 77 hours approximately.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So comparing all cases: - 2001: ~1.5 hours - 2002: ~26.9 hours (~1.1 days) - 2003: ~50.33 hours (~2.1 days) - 2004: ~1.4 hours - 2005: ~77 hours (~3.2 days) Looking at these, cases 2002, 2003, 2005 are taking longer. But how much is significantly longer? Let's see the average. The shortest is around 1.5 hours, the next is 26 hours, then 50, then 77. The difference between 2001 and 2002 is a day, so maybe cases that take more than a day are considered problematic. But maybe even 26 hours is over a day. Let's see the process steps. Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Wait, actually, let me recalculate the durations precisely. Case 2001: Submit at 9:00 AM, Close at 10:30 AM same day. So 1.5 hours. Case 2002: Submit 9:05 AM April 1, Close 11:00 AM April 2. That's 24 hours minus 9:05 + 22 hours 55 minutes? Wait, 9:05 to 11:00 next day: from 9:05 to 9:05 next day is 24h, then another 1h55m. So total 25h55m? Wait, maybe better to compute the exact difference. The difference between April 2nd 11:00 and April 1st 9:05 is (24 - 9.083) + 11.0 (since 9:05 is 9 + 5/60 hours 9.0833). Wait, better to compute in hours: April 1 9:05 to April 2 11:00 is 25 hours 55 minutes. So 25.92 hours. Case 2003: submit 9:10, close on April 3 at 9:30 AM. The time from start to end: April 1 to April 3 is 2 days, 9:30 -9:10 is 20 minutes. So total is 2 days and 20 minutes. That's 48h20m, but wait, let's compute exact: April 1 9:10 to April 3 9:30 is 48 hours plus 20 minutes. So 48.33 hours. Case 2005: Submit 9:25 on April 1, closes on April 4 at 14:30. From 9:25 to 14:30 is 3 days and 5 hours 5 minutes. So total: April 1 9:25 to April 4 09:25 is exactly 3 days (72 hours). Then from 09:25 to 14:30 on the 4th is 5 hours 5 minutes. Total: 72 + 5.083 (5h5m is 5.083 hours) so total 77.08 hours. Okay, so the durations are: 2001: 1.5h 2002: ~25.9h 2003: ~50.5h 2004: 1.4h 2005: ~77h Comparing these, Cases 2002, 2003, 2005 are longer. Cases 2001 and 2004 are normal. So the first task is to identify which are significantly longer. Since 25 hours is over a day, and 50 is 2 days, and 77 is over 3 days. The others are under 2 hours. So the significantly longer ones are 2002, 2003, 2005.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
